ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Definitely, you learn so much about South Africa in a very chill class setting.
Its an investigation of the transition of South Africa from a colony to the rainbow nation it is today. However, it looks at the many struggles the country has had with race, identity, and language.
A big lesson on South African history and culture basically, in the context of language and identity. Very interesting. I recommend it to anyone. One of my best classes at yale.

Without a doubt, one of the most stimulating and well taught classes at Yale. I enjoyed learning more than I could ever imagine about South African history, culture and languages through a diverse mix of films and scholarly articles. Language is the ESSENTIAL issue in South Africa today, and you will explore the different language groups from a cultural standpoint, and how the multilingual society works in practice. Professor Sanneh has a wealth of knowledge and structured the class perfectly to allow for a good balance between lecture, discussion and student presentations .

I would say it is a great class about the various different groups in South Africa. We cover how some of them have evolved and how they have shaped the South Africa that exists today. The class draws on a variety of great source material and is very interesting.
This is an AWESOME class and I would 100% recommend it to anyone. Professor Sanneh is wonderful! Very interesting reading and watching assignments as well.
